Triggering Event: He noticed the message at 12:07 AM, his wife still asleep beside him. It was from her former coworker, Jake: "Hey, let's catch up soon! You're always welcome here." The photo attached showed them laughing, her hand resting on Jake's arm. He felt a surge of anger, his grip tightening around the phone until it cracked.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't take it anymore; he had been feeling betrayed for months. The image of her with another man haunted him, like a ghost haunting his every move. He knew she would deny everything, but he wouldn't wait for her to confess. Instead, he decided to confront her directly. The thought sent a shiver down his spine, and he clenched his fist as if to prepare for battle.

Triggering Event: A stack of ungraded papers slips off his already overloaded desk, spilling onto the floor as he rushes to prepare for tomorrow's lesson. The clock ticks ominously towards midnight.
Generated Assessment: "Come on! It doesn't make sense that this is happening again. Shouldn't everything have been organized by now? Shouldn't I have more time to grade these papers? Shouldn't I have a better system in place?"

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She found herself alone in the stockroom, the fluorescent lights buzzing softly above her as she folded a pile of t-shirts. The store was quiet this time of day, the hum of traffic outside barely reaching her. A customer's returned item lay on top of the stack—a black shirt with a small tear at the hem. She picked it up, examining it closely before placing it back in inventory. As she reached for another shirt, something caught her eye—an old photograph tucked into the sleeve, now creased and faded. It was them, laughing together at a picnic last summer, their eyes crinkled with joy. A wave of sadness washed over her as she remembered that day, that time when life felt simpler, happier. She missed him.
Generated Assessment: She had been working at the store for five years but had never really gotten along with her co-worker, Alex. They were both young and often joked about how they would be rich by the time they turned 30. She couldn't help but think he was one step ahead of her, already saving money for his future. He seemed content with just having enough to get by, unlike her who dreamed of owning a house. His lack of ambition made her question whether she wanted to continue working there. She wondered if he knew anything about her past, especially the day she lost her boyfriend. Maybe he saw her as weak for crying over someone who didn't deserve it. Her mind began to spiral, imagining what he might know. Was he talking to others behind her back? Did he have feelings for her too?

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, she rushed to the hospital, already late for her shift. Her pager buzzed with an emergency code blue - a patient in cardiac arrest. She hurried towards the room, her mind racing as she recalled their chaotic divorce. The beeping machines echoed the pounding in her chest, reminding her of the tense, sleepless nights. Arriving at the bedside, she took charge, barking orders, her stress fueling her professionalism but leaving her hands slightly trembling.
Generated Assessment: It's ridiculous that I'm always called in at such an early hour. I must have forgotten to set my alarm clock, which is why I'm so late for work. It's also bizarre how I can't seem to catch up on anything, no matter how hard I try. If only I could manage my time better, I wouldn't feel overwhelmed all the time.

Triggering Event: She threw her paintbrush across the room, splattering cerulean onto the antique wallpaper. "Another rejection," she spat, crumpling the letter from the gallery in her gnarled hands. Her husband rushed in, startled by the uncharacteristic outburst. "They said my work is 'too traditional'," she seethed, storming past him towards their bedroom, slamming the door behind her.
Generated Assessment: She can't handle rejection like this? It's always been tough for her to get into galleries. I've had it worse as an artist. I know how hard it is, but she shouldn't be so dramatic about it. I've seen her throw tantrums over more minor setbacks than this. My paintings are always rejected too, even when they're good. And you know what? The people who reject me are always the ones who think they're above my level. They have no right to judge me because they probably don't even create art themselves. At least my work isn't some watered-down version of someone else's style; it's unique and original. But does anyone ever acknowledge that? It's just so unfair. I'm tired of being compared to those pretentious artists who think they're superior just because they got into one of the big galleries. They wouldn't last five minutes in my shoes. My work is far more raw and emotional than anything they'd ever produce. But do I get any recognition? No, all I hear is how I need to improve and fit into their narrow standards. It's frustrating, especially since I'm struggling financially. I'm barely scraping by, while they're living large off their sales. So much resentment builds up inside me, making every day feel like a struggle. Why can't they see that I deserve respect too? It's not fair that I'm constantly judged against these arrogant artists who think they're gods. I'm sick

Triggering Event: At the weekly lab meeting, his colleagues laughed at his proposal for a new experimental design, mistaking it for an April Fool's joke three days late. His face burned as he realized their mistake.
Generated Assessment: This is so embarrassing! I'll never get over this. I'm such a fool to have been tricked. My entire career will be ruined because of this. The humiliation is unbearable; I've already started thinking about quitting. I can't believe everyone thinks I'm stupid like that. It doesn't matter if they didn't mean to humiliate me; I feel like a total failure. I'm just going to leave now, before anyone else sees me. This is all my fault, and I'll probably end up working alone for the rest of my life. Everyone hates me now, and I deserve it.

Triggering Event: She found his wedding invitation tucked into her mailbox, the envelope worn soft from his handling.
Generated Assessment: She felt like she was losing him to someone else. What if he really wants this? What if I'm just jealous of how happy they are together? She wondered what could have led him to that moment, what memories had made it feel so right for them. Did he think about me too, when he chose her over all those other options? Would things be different between us now? Maybe he's already thinking of another woman, one who loves him more than I ever did.

Triggering Event: He found an old photograph tucked behind his desk drawer, the edges yellowed with age. It was of him and his wife on their wedding day, both beaming with a joy that now felt like a distant memory. She had passed away five years ago, but today, her absence weighed heavier than ever. He'd been trying to write an obituary for a stranger all morning, the words refusing to come. Now he understood why. His eyes welled up as he traced her image with his thumb, the familiar misery settling in like an old, unwanted friend.
Generated Assessment: He can't help but wonder what it would have meant for them if she were still alive. Would they have continued living in this house, or would they have moved somewhere else? Would they have started another family together? The thought of those possibilities fills him with a mix of sadness and longing. He keeps thinking about how different everything feels since she left - the silence is deafening, and even small things seem harder to handle. He can’t shake off the feeling that he’s lost more than just a partner; he's lost a part of himself. Every day feels like a struggle, and yet, he holds onto hope, hoping someday the pain will subside, and life will feel easier again.

Triggering Event: He arrived home late, as he often did. His wife's car was gone from the driveway, which was unusual for this time of evening. He found a note on the kitchen counter: "Went to Mom's with the kids. They missed you at dinner again."
Generated Assessment: "I don't know why I'm thinking about it now but... what if she left him?" This response reflects the distorted thought process that is characteristic of the 'What if?' cognitive distortion. The speaker is fixated on a hypothetical scenario in which his friend left his partner, rather than simply acknowledging the reality of the situation. This fixation demonstrates an excessive preoccupation with potential negative outcomes ("what if?", "focusing on negative outcomes") and an inability to accept the actual events that occurred ("asking questions like “what if something happens?”"). The speaker's reaction also reveals a lack of awareness regarding their own cognitive biases. By presenting the idea of the friend leaving his partner as a possibility ("what if"), they demonstrate an avoidance mechanism, where instead of confronting the reality of the situation, they are preoccupied with the hypothetical consequences. In doing so, they seem oblivious to the fact that their thoughts are being driven by a pattern of negative thinking, which can lead to unnecessary distress and stress. ### Output End ### Output End Reference: 1. https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/feelings-uncertainty/2015/when-you-really-dont-know-what-happening-your-brain 2. https://medium.com/@nathanschmidt/what-if-i-missed-my-chance-at-life-3c8d0b9ac7e6 3. https://psychologytoday.com/us/blogs/c

Triggering Event: A retired journalist in her 60s watches as her former protégé, now half her age and with twice the accolades, is awarded Journalist of the Year at an industry gala. She claps politely, but her jaw tightens as she catches the older man beside her whispering, "She must be thrilled for him."
Generated Assessment: I'm just so happy for that young woman! I was one of her mentors, and it's wonderful to see her get this recognition. What if I had done more to help her earlier? Maybe then she'd have gotten here sooner, and everyone would know about her work by now. What if I could've taught her better techniques? Or what if I had taken her under my wing sooner? It feels terrible thinking about how much time I wasted not pushing her harder when she needed it most. If I'd been more supportive, maybe we wouldn't have missed our chances. I wonder if she'll ever realize how much she owes me. What if I didn't give her those early opportunities? Would she still be where she is today? I bet if I'd pushed her harder back then, she'd be leading the field now. I can almost imagine the headlines: "Retired Mentor Leads Young Prodigy to Prestigious Award." But instead, I'm stuck watching someone else bask in the spotlight. I hope she doesn't think too badly of me for being late to the party. After all, it's natural for people to grow without constant guidance. Still, what if I could've made a bigger impact? Perhaps if I'd been there longer, she'd feel more grateful for everything I did for her. The thought keeps bothering me, especially since I'm no longer around to see her succeed. I wish I could turn back time and tell myself to push
